intro: Gilia liniflora subsp. pharnaceoides, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of pink to purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or gravelly soils. The species is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient component of desert ecosystems.
